bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, April 12, 1940

div1.p: Moran inquires about his draft letter for Pew and comments on Agramonte's letter regarding Carroll's case of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, April 12, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, April 12, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Just a few hurried lines to welcome Mrs. Hench and your good
self back to that grand old institution, seat of your professional act-
ivities, and at the same time to send you my check for conversion of
your Cuban Pesos into American Dollars.

You bought the THIRTY-FOUR PESOS at 87¢ each, so I am buying
them back from you at NO LOSS AND NO PROFIT for you. Is that OK?
Herewith, therefore, my check on THE FIRST NATIONAL BANK OF BOSTON in
amount of TWENTY-NINE & 58/100 DOLLARS ($29.58).

Elida reminds me that I did not deliver her message in full,
with reference to the handkerchief, to Mrs. Hench. The missing part
of the message was to the effect that the handkerchief had been washed
just once since she bought it, in 1921, hence its present yellow color.
Needless to add that the handkerchief has never been used.

Elida told me last night that she tried to get me at my office
before I started out for the Terminal to bid you God Speed and farewell,
so that I could thank you for your beautiful gift of flowers. It was
most thoughtful of you both to send them, so please accept our joint
thanks for the delicate message the conveyed to us. I am sorry I could
not deliver this message in person.

The suggested letter to Mr. Pew, which you will have perused by
this time, so far as the name I invented for the “LAZEAR MEMORIAL” is
purely fictitious and used by me instead of so many dashes or dots in
blank. I had forgotten to dot down the name, if given, from Doctor
Hutchison's letter which you were kind enough to show me.

The matters you left pending with Sr. Pogolotti and your very
humble servant will have our very prompt attention. I have tried with-
out sucess to get in touch with the photographer this forenoon, but hope
to have better luck this afternoon.

Elida joins me in affectionate remembrances to Mrs. Hench and
yourself.

closer.seg:
P. S. The Agramonte letter is a “stunner”
and confirms, to my mind, reading between
the lines, my suspicions as to Dr. C's
“experimental yellow fever”
J. J. M.
